snippet: Officials across Europe were calling for even stronger border controls, stricter screening of migrants and some way to reduce the flow.
abstract: Wave of apprehension about Middle East migrants sweeps across Europe after terrorist attacks in Paris, jeopardizing hard-won recent agreement on resettling refugees; some citizens and politicians, particularly in Eastern Europe, intensify anti-immigrant rhetoric, while others stress that refugees are fleeing Islamic terror themselves.

byline.original: By RICK LYMAN and ALISON SMALE
byline.contributor: Rick Lyman reported from Warsaw, and Alison Smale from Berlin. Reporting was contributed by Barbara Sulk in Ljubljana, Slovenia; Kit Gillet in Bucharest, Romania; Hana de Goeij in Prague; Miroslava Germanova in Bratislava, Slovakia; Boryana Dzhambazova in Edirne, Turkey; and Richard Martyn-Hemphill in Riga, Latvia.

lead_paragraph: Officials across Europe were calling for even stronger border controls, stricter screening of migrants and some way to reduce the flow.

headline.main: Paris Attacks Shift Europe’s Migrant Focus to Security
headline.print_headline: Attacks Change Europe’s Migrant Focus From Compassion to Security

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
